misconceptions.name: Implemented an entirely different problem (distance formula) instead of a grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program that reads two coordinate points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and computes the distance between them, rather than reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and mapping it to a letter grade using conditional ranges as specified in the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the assignment is to compute the distance between two points given their coordinates, rather than to read a numeric grade and output a corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt for a single numeric grade between 0 and 100, store that value, and use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to determine and print the correct letter grade: A for 90-100, B for 80-89, C for 70-79, D for 60-69, and F for below 60.
symptoms: Prompts for 'Enter x1 and y1' and 'Enter x2 and y2' instead of a grade
Reads four double values instead of a single numeric grade
No conditional logic to check grade ranges
Outputs 'The distance of the two points is ...' instead of a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements, likely confusing this question with a distance-formula exercise or reusing code from a different assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and identify the required inputs (a single numeric grade), the processing (checking which numeric range the grade falls into with conditionals), and the required output (a letter grade). Start by writing pseudocode for reading one grade and using if/else if/else to decide which letter to print.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (inputs, variables, computation, and output message) is aligned with a distance formula problem and none of it addresses reading a grade or mapping ranges to letters.

evidence.note: Instead of reading a single numeric grade, the code reads four doubles labeled as coordinate components (x1, y1, x2, y2).

evidence.snippet:
double d=Math.sqrt((x2-x1)*(x2-x1)+(y2-y1)*(y2-y1));
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is "+d);
evidence.note: The computation and output clearly implement a distance-between-two-points calculation, not a letter grade mapping.

misconceptions.name: Failure to address required task
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a program designed to calculate the distance between two points (a program unrelated to the prompt) instead of the required Grade Calculator program.
misconceptions.student_belief: The submitted code, which calculates the distance between two points, satisfies the requirements of this assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires a program to read a single numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional logic (if/else statements) to output the corresponding letter grade based on the given scale (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Code reads four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade.
Program calculates mathematical distance instead of determining a letter grade.
No conditional logic (if/else) related to grade ranges exists.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements or submitting code intended for a different question.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the prompt for Q3 (Grade Calculator) and ensure the submitted code addresses the required input handling, conditional logic for grading, and output format.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is a correct implementation of the Euclidean Distance formula, which is definitively not the Grade Calculator requested.

evidence.note: The code reads four doubles and calculates Euclidean distance, completely ignoring the task of reading a single grade and calculating a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student has implemented a completely different program (distance calculator between two points) instead of the required grade calculator program.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either misread the assignment or submitted code for a different problem (Q2 or another question).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A-F) based on specified ranges. The program should use conditional statements to check which range the grade falls into.
symptoms: Program reads two coordinate pairs (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) instead of a single grade
Program calculates Euclidean distance instead of mapping grades to letters
Output shows distance calculation instead of letter grade
No conditional logic for grade ranges (if/else statements for A, B, C, D, F)
misconceptions.root_cause: Complete misunderstanding or misreading of the problem requirements. The student may have submitted the wrong file or confused this problem with another assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The program should: (1) read a single integer grade, (2) use if-else statements to check which range it falls into, (3) print the corresponding letter grade. Start over with the correct problem.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence because the submitted code solves an entirely different problem (distance between points) with no attempt to address grade calculation or letter grading logic.

evidence.note: The entire program implements a distance calculator, not a grade calculator. This indicates the student either submitted the wrong file or fundamentally misunderstood the assignment.

misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem instead of the specified grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The program computes the distance between two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) rather than reading a numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade as required. There is no single grade input, no grade range checks, and no letter-grade output.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this task by writing a program that reads two points and outputs the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to read ONE numeric grade value between 0 and 100, then use conditional statements to determine whether it falls into the A, B, C, D, or F range, and finally print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for 'Enter x1 and y1:' and 'Enter x2 and y2:' instead of asking for a grade.
Four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) are read instead of a single numeric grade.
The main computation uses the distance formula with Math.sqrt and coordinate differences.
No if/else or conditional logic exists to test grade ranges.
Output describes a distance ('The distance of the two points is ...') rather than a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have confused this assignment with a different one (distance between two points) or did not carefully read and follow the problem specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement step by step. Start by writing code that reads a single numeric grade. Then, design if/else-if conditions that check the ranges 90–100, 80–89, 70–79, 60–69, and below 60, and print the correct letter for each case. Avoid reusing code from unrelated problems unless it matches the current specification.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (inputs, calculations, outputs) corresponds to a distance-formula problem and none of it addresses reading a grade or producing a letter grade, so it is clear the assignment requirements were misinterpreted.

evidence.note: This code reads four coordinate values and computes a distance instead of reading a single grade and mapping it to a letter with conditionals.

evidence.note: The entire logic and I/O handlers are geared towards calculating distance, not grading.
